description: Added methods _is_valid and _validate_header to GadgetDataset class so that load can process Gadget raw binary snapshots. Also, added unit handling for non-cosmological simulations to GadgetSimulation class (units were only being set for cosmological simulations).
title: Gadget raw binary snapshot handling & non-cosmological simulation units

pullrequest.title: Gadget raw binary snapshot handling & non-cosmological simulation units

content.raw: What happens if the parameter file isn't available or specified at load time? This information isn't in the binary output right?
content.html: What happens if the parameter file isn't available or specified at load time? This information isn't in the binary output right?

content.raw: Awesome, thanks for implementing this!
content.html: Awesome, thanks for implementing this!

pullrequest.title: Gadget raw binary snapshot handling & non-cosmological simulation units

content.raw: We should test that this is working.  Take a look at th tests in the other front ends to see how we handle it.
content.html: We should test that this is working. Take a look at th tests in the other front ends to see how we handle it.

pullrequest.title: Gadget raw binary snapshot handling & non-cosmological simulation units

content.raw: The information is not in the binary, but the GadgetSimulation class is initialized based on the provided parameter file so it will always be available.
content.html: The information is not in the binary, but the GadgetSimulation class is initialized based on the provided parameter file so it will always be available.

content.raw: I added `IsothermalCollapse` a while back on http://yt-project.org/data/.  If you do decide to use the one you have, we need to make sure it gets added to the data hub.

pullrequest.title: Gadget raw binary snapshot handling & non-cosmological simulation units

content.raw:
We should also update this page in the docs: http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/examining/loading_data.html#gadget-data

In principle we can also deprecate the `GadgetDataset` import in `yt/__init__.py`, but that can also be left as is for now without hurting anything.
content.html:
We should also update this page in the docs: http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/examining/loading_data.html#gadget-data

In principle we can also deprecate the GadgetDataset import in yt/__init__.py, but that can also be left as is for now without hurting anything.

pullrequest.title: Gadget raw binary snapshot handling & non-cosmological simulation units

content.raw: Really? I think it is required; the SimulationTimeSeries class (super class to GadgetSimulation) raises an error if the file does not exist.
content.html: Really? I think it is required; the SimulationTimeSeries class (super class to GadgetSimulation) raises an error if the file does not exist.

content.html: Ah, neat. Not a big deal though; I seem to recall actually supporting SnapFormat=2 requires a bunch more boilerplate.

pullrequest.title: Gadget raw binary snapshot handling & non-cosmological simulation units

content.raw:
It actually doesn't look like there's a way to specify the parameter file when loading a Gadget file.  Am I missing that somewhere?

I tested this with `IsothermalCollapse` and it seems to work like a charm!
content.html:
It actually doesn't look like there's a way to specify the parameter file when loading a Gadget file. Am I missing that somewhere?

I tested this with IsothermalCollapse and it seems to work like a charm!

pullrequest.title: Gadget raw binary snapshot handling & non-cosmological simulation units

content.raw: Actually, on second pass, it looks like their read script allows both so I'm not sure what format they are in...
content.html: Actually, on second pass, it looks like their read script allows both so I'm not sure what format they are in...

pullrequest.title: Gadget raw binary snapshot handling & non-cosmological simulation units

content.raw: No there isn't, this is something that would be nice to implement though (I was about to start on this) and would allow for setting things like units, box size, and the cosmological simulation flag automatically. However, this could get confusing since the snapshot filename is stored as the parameter_filename attribute.
content.html: No there isn't, this is something that would be nice to implement though (I was about to start on this) and would allow for setting things like units, box size, and the cosmological simulation flag automatically. However, this could get confusing since the snapshot filename is stored as the parameter_filename attribute.

pullrequest.title: Gadget raw binary snapshot handling & non-cosmological simulation units

content.raw:
Yeah, I *think* we could make it point at a parameter file if one is available without breaking things.  Is it the standard to give them a `.param` suffix?  If so we could search for a `.param` sidecar file in the same directory as the dataset.

All this doesn't need to happen in this PR btw.
content.html:
Yeah, I think we could make it point at a parameter file if one is available without breaking things. Is it the standard to give them a .param suffix? If so we could search for a .param sidecar file in the same directory as the dataset.

All this doesn't need to happen in this PR btw.

pullrequest.title: Gadget raw binary snapshot handling & non-cosmological simulation units

content.raw: Yes, .param is the standard so if one is not provided, a search can be done. Also, it could be as easy as just creating a gadget_parameter_file attribute.
content.html: Yes, .param is the standard so if one is not provided, a search can be done. Also, it could be as easy as just creating a gadget_parameter_file attribute.

content.raw: @xarthisius is it possible that NMSU-ART uses the same header info?
content.html: Kacper Kowalik is it possible that NMSU-ART uses the same header info?

pullrequest.title: Gadget raw binary snapshot handling & non-cosmological simulation units

content.raw: Well at least first 4 bytes are equal to 65536 which confuses `load()`
content.html: Well at least first 4 bytes are equal to 65536 which confuses load()

pullrequest.title: Gadget raw binary snapshot handling & non-cosmological simulation units

content.raw:
One possibility to get around this is also read the 4 byte footer following the header block, which should be 256 (exactly 256 bytes after the first 4 bytes).

EDIT: This does not work, it looks like the headers have the same length.
content.html:
One possibility to get around this is also read the 4 byte footer following the header block, which should be 256 (exactly 256 bytes after the first 4 bytes).

EDIT: This does not work, it looks like the headers have the same length.

pullrequest.title: Gadget raw binary snapshot handling & non-cosmological simulation units

content.raw: In the tipsy frontend we read in the number of each particle type, then calculate what the total file size should be and compare with the actual file size. See `_validate_header` in `yt/frontends/tipsy/data_structures.py`.
content.html: In the tipsy frontend we read in the number of each particle type, then calculate what the total file size should be and compare with the actual file size. See _validate_header in yt/frontends/tipsy/data_structures.py.

pullrequest.title: Gadget raw binary snapshot handling & non-cosmological simulation units

content.raw: A "best guess" is probably sufficient; since Gadget doesn't use AUX files (as Tipsy does) we don't want to have to parse all the possible field types, etc.  I think maybe just looking at the very next block, seeing how long it is and if it's the length of the particle count, should suffice.
content.html: A "best guess" is probably sufficient; since Gadget doesn't use AUX files (as Tipsy does) we don't want to have to parse all the possible field types, etc. I think maybe just looking at the very next block, seeing how long it is and if it's the length of the particle count, should suffice.

pullrequest.title: Gadget raw binary snapshot handling & non-cosmological simulation units

content.raw: Fixed this by comparing the number of particles in the header to the size of the position block at Matt's suggestion. The total file size would be tricky since some snapshots can contain the addition potential and acceleration fields depending on the Makefile options.
content.html: Fixed this by comparing the number of particles in the header to the size of the position block at Matt's suggestion. The total file size would be tricky since some snapshots can contain the addition potential and acceleration fields depending on the Makefile options.
